Name: Actinomyces
Key Points: Present in normal human flora

Name: Ascaris lumbricoides
Key Points: Giant roundworm (helminth)

Name: Bacillus anthracis
Key Points: Cutaneous form has low mortality; Inhalational form has high mortality; Potential biological weapon
Treatment: Ciprofloaxcin, doxycycline, penicillin; Treatment must be initiated ASAP to avoid death (especially for inhalational)

Name: Bacillus cereus
Key Points: Pre-formed toxin; Fried rice

Name: Bacteroides fragilis
Key Points: Normal colonic flora

Name: Bartonella henselae
Key Points: Cat scratches

Name: Bordetella pertussis
Treatment: Erythromycin; Azithromycin in kids <1 to avoid pyloric stenosis
Prevention: Vaccine (DTaP in kids, Tdap in adults)
Signs: Catarrhal phase (infectious); Paroxysmal phase (cough)

Name: Borrelia burgdorferi
Key Points: Ixodes tick (deer tick)
Treatment: Doxycycline; Amoxicillin, or cefuroxime in kids <8
Signs: Erythema migrans (bulls eye); Diffuse arthrgias; Bell's palsy; Aseptic meningitis; Carditis; Complete heart block

Name: Campylobacter jejuni
Key Points: Tiny Gull-shaped rods; Associated with chicken
Disease: Diarrhea; Guillain Barre syndrome; Reiters Syndrome

Name: Chlamydia trachomatis
Key Points: Causitave agent of Chlamydia
Treatment: Pelvic: Doxycycline or azithromycin; Eye: Oral erythromycin

Name: Chlamydophila pneumoniae
Key Points: Common cause of "walking pneumonia"; high seroprevalence among adults
General: Intracellular pathogen; Reticulate Body (RB): intracellular, replicative form; Elementary Body (EB): extracellular, infectious form

Name: Clonorchis sinensis
Key Points: Cholangiocarcinoma; associated with ingestion of infected freshwater fish
General: Also known as "Chinese liver fluke"; commonly distributed throughout Asia
Signs: Chronic: usually asymptomatic with intermittent abdominal pain, fatigue, anorexia, dyspepsia; Acute (rare): abodminal pain, fever, fatigue, anorexia, hepatomegaly, eosinophilia

Name: Clostridium botulinum
Key Points: Associated with raw honey; Produces highly potent paralytic toxin
General: Strict anaerobe; Disease due to botulinum toxin; Can form stable spores
Treatment: Botulinum antitoxin; Ventilation if respiratory involvement
Signs: Progressive flaccid paralysis

Name: Clostridium difficile
Key Points: GI disease after antibiotic treatment; Easily spread in hospitals
Treatment: Metronidazole + vancomycin (or fidaxomicin); Human monoclonal anti-toxin B

Name: Clostridium perfringens
Key Points: Associated with cooked meat (esp. beef)

Name: Clostridium tetani
Key Points: Causative agent of tetanus; Classically associated with wounds involving rusted metal (i.e. nails)
General: Sporeformer; Strict anaerobe; Caused by infections of wounds by spores
Laboratory: No major lab tests; Diagnosis based primarily based on H&P
Treatment: Tetanus Immunoglobulin (TIG); mechanical ventilation may be needed in severe cases
Prevention: Vaccine (DTaP in kids, Tdap or Td in adults)
Signs: Trismus ("lockjaw"); Arching of back muscles (opisthotonus); Severe and painful spasms of skeletal muscle

Name: Corynebacterium diphtheriae
Key Points: Largely eliminated in US due to vaccination
Treatment: Antitoxin to neutralize toxin, antibiotics to eradicate organisms
Prevention: Vaccine (DTaP in kids, Tdap in adults)

Name: Coxsackievirus
Disease: Hand, foot, and mouth disease; Herpangina; Pleurodynia (Bornholm disease)

Name: Cryptosporidium parvum
Key Points: Unchlorinated pool water

Name: Cyclospora cayetanensis
Key Points: Reported in tropical and subtropical regions

Name: Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
Disease: Chorioretinitis; Encephalitis; Microcephaly; Periventricular calcifications in the brain (cmV = periVentricular); Esophagitis; Gastritis

Name: Diphyllobothrium latum
Key Points: Fish tapeworm url:https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/42/D_latum_LifeCycle.png

Name: Eastern Equine Encephalitis (EEE)
Signs: Flu-like symptoms

Name: Echinococcus granulosus
Key Points: Associated with contamination of dog feces; Cyst rupture can trigger anphylaxis
General: Worms that predominantly invade liver, followed by lungs
Disease: Anaphylaxis; Cholangitis/biliary obstruction; Peritonitis if intraperitoneal; Pneumonia if in lungs
Signs: Symptoms due to cyst rupture

Name: Entamoeba histolytica
Key Points: Liver abscess with "anchovy paste" contents; Parasite "eats" RBCs
General: Humans are only known host; Associated with fecal contamination of water
Laboratory: Visualization in stool (O&P x3); Extraintestinal: needle aspiration, serology
Disease: Intestinal and extraintestinal ameobiasis; Prominent flask-shaped ulcers in colon; Lactose intolerance post-infection
Signs: Mucoid, bloody stools; Weight loss; Abdominal pain; Fever

Name: Enteroaggregative Escherichia coli (EAggEC or EAEC)
Key Points: Stacked brick appearance
Signs: Inflammatory diarrhea with occasional blood and mucus

Name: Enterobius vermicularis
Key Points: AKA "Pinworm"
Signs: Anal itching

Name: Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC)
Key Points: Hamburger; Hemolytic uremic syndrome; Hemorrhagic colitis; Hold the antibiotics!
Disease: Hemorrhagic colitis (bloody diarrhea); Hemolytic uremic syndrome

Name: Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli (EIEC)
Key Points: I for identical to Shigella but doesn't produce Shiga toxin
Signs: Watery diarrhea to dysentery

Name: Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC)
Key Points: P for protracted, pediatric diarrhea in poor countries; Plasmid-mediated virulence factors; Pedestal formation; Passive protection from breast milk

Name: Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC)
Key Points: T for Traveler; Two toxins LT and ST
Signs: Watery diarrhea

Name: Escherichia coli
Key Points: Associated with fecal contamination

Name: Fasciola hepatica
Key Points: Transmission associated with aquatic plants; Major agricultural pathogen throughout world

Name: Gardnerella vaginalis
Key Points: Common cause of bacterial vaginosis
Signs: Gray vaginal discharge with fishy odor

Name: Giardia lamblia
Key Points: Associated with mountain stream water
Signs: Flatulence, steatorrhea, "foul smelling stools"; Weight loss; Debilitation

Name: Haemophilus influenzae
Key Points: Classic respiratory bug
General: Six capsular types; Type B prominent in unvaccinated populations; Non-typable strains increasingly prominent
Laboratory: Growth requires X and V factors (Chocolate Agar); Oxidase positive
Disease: Acute otitis media (AOM); Meningitis (particularly in unvaccinated children); Pneumonia; Upper respiratory infection (URI)

Name: Helicobacter pylori
Key Points: Type I carcinogen; Major cause of peptic ulcers
Laboratory: Urease positive; Giemsa stain; Wurthin-Starry stain; IgG Serology (ever infected); Fecal antigen test (current infection); Urea breath test (current infection)
Treatment: Triple therapy (10-14 days) PPI (esomeprazole), Amoxicillin, Clarithromycin; Quadruple therapy (10-14 days) PPI (esomeprazole), Metronidazole, Tetracycline, Bismuth subsalicylate
Disease: Gastritis; Gastric adenocarcinoma; Gastric ulcers; MALT lymphoma

Name: Hepatitis A
Key Points: Associated with contaminated water or shellfish
Signs: Fever; Abdominal pain; Jaundice

Name: Hepatitis B
Key Points: Spread by sexual contact
Laboratory: anti-HBsAb = vaccinated; anti-HBcAb = current or previous infection; anti-HBeAb = actively dividing; HBsAg + anti-HBc IgM + anti-HBc = acute infection; HBsAg + anti-HBc = chronic infection

Name: Hepatitis C
Key Points: Blood transfusion related; IV Drug use
General: Commonly progresses to chronic hepatitis infection

Name: Hepatitis D
Key Points: Requires Hepatitis B infection to replicate
Prevention: Vaccination against Hepatitis B typically preventative

Name: Hepatitis E
Key Points: Increased mortality in pregnant women

Name: Herpes Simplex Virus
Key Points: Vertical Transmission (TORCHeS infection); HSV-1 latent in trigeminal ganglia; HSV-2 latent in sacral ganglia
Morphology: Double-Stranded, Linear, Enveloped DNA virus; icosahedral capsid
Laboratory: Fluoroscein slit lamp exam shows corneal ulcers; Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells
Disease: Encephalitis; Keratoconjunctivitis; Herpes labialis; Gingivostomatitis; Aseptic meningitis
Signs: Cold sores; Erythema multiforme; Inguinal lymphadenopathy (HSV-2)

Name: Histoplasma capsulatum
Key Points: Predominantly occurs in Ohio River valley region
Morphology: Dimorphic fungus (yeast form in active infection)
Treatment: Supportive for mild; Itraconazole for moderate; Amphotericin B for severe infection

Name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)
Key Points: Causative agent of AIDS
Prevention: Standard Precautions; Safe sexual practices and screening; PREP url:https://www.cdc.gov/std/tg2015/clinical.htm#prep
Signs: Children: Seizures, motor deficits, acquired microcephaly, behavioral and cognitive decline

Name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV)
Key Points: Common STI; Strong association with many cancers (SCC and cervical)
Prevention: HPV Vaccine (Gardasil)-targets HPV strains 6 and 11 (genital warts) and 16 and 18 (cervical cancer)
Disease: Genital warts (papilloma, condyloma, verruca vulgaris); Cervical cancer; Squamous esophageal carcinoma; Esophagitis

Name: Japanese Encephalitis virus
Prevention: Inactivated mouse brain-derived vaccine; Inactivated Vero cell-derived vaccine; Live attenuated vaccine; Live recombinant vaccine
Signs: Flu-like symptoms; Fever, rash, aches, chills

Name: JC Virus
Key Points: Immunocompromised host

Name: Klebsiella pneumoniae
Key Points: Associated with infection of immunocompromised patients
Prevention: Hand-washing; Gown and gloves in infected areas

Name: La Crosse virus
Signs: Flu-like symptoms

Name: Legionella pneumophilia
Key Points: Pulmonary pathogen associated with contaminated water; Uniquely associated with GI symptoms
General: Often transmitted through contaminated water; Intracellular pathogen; Associated with age and immunosuppression
Gram Stain: Gram-negative (does not take up gram stain in sputum)
Laboratory: BCYE for growth (uncommon); Serology; Antigen testing (from urine or bronchoalveolar lavage)
Disease: Legionellosis (Legionnaire's disease); Pontiac Fever; Atypical pneumonia
Signs: Fever; Chills; Headache; Pneumonia; GI symptoms

Name: Listeria monocytogenes
Key Points: Associated with cold cuts/lunch meat and ice cream
General: Food-borne pathogen; Psychrophilic (grows at cold temperatures) or mesophilic (grows at moderate temperatures); Facultative intracellular pathogen (cell mediated immunity); Motile, hemolytic, non-spore-forming; Listeriolysin O (virulence factor); Moves within cells by using host actin polymerization
Laboratory: Facultative anaerobe; Nonsporulating; Catalase and CAMP test positive; Beta-hemolytic
Prevention: Proper food handling and cooking; Avoid raw/unpasteurized milk or milk products
Signs: Flu-like illness

Name: Malassezia furfur
Key Points: Associated with neonates receiving lipid infusions or TPN
General: Confined to stratum corneum, damages melanocytes through lipid degradation
Morphology: KOH prep shows "spaghetti and meatball" appearance url:https://img.medscapestatic.com/pi/meds/ckb/66/43166tn.jpg
Signs: Hypo and hyper pigmented skin patches

Name: Measles virus
Disease: Measles; Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis 10 years after infection
Signs: Maculopapular rash spreading from face to body; Cough; Coryza; Conjunctivitis; Koplik’s spots (mouth)

Name: Moraxella (Branhamella) catarrhalis
Key Points: Classic respiratory bug
Disease: Acute otitis media (AOM);  Upper respiratory infection (URI)

Name: Mumps virus
Disease: Aseptic meningitis; Meningoencephalitis; Unilateral nerve deafness; Epididymoorchitis
Signs: Swollen, painful salivary glands on one or both sides of face

Name: Micobacterium avium
Key Points: AIDS defining; CD4 < 50
Disease: Micobacerium Avium Complex (MAC) infection with 3+ micobacterium species

Name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Laboratory: Positive PPD test (false-positives with previous BCG vaccination); Chest X-ray, Positive Interferon gamma assay
Signs: Upper lobe cavitary lesion

Name: Mycoplasma pneumoniae
General: Cause of atypical pneumonia, especially in school children, young adults in close proxmity, and elderly
Gram Stain: No cell wall; do not gram stain
Laboratory: Serology, cold agglutination; Laboratory growth requires serum
Signs: Variable; can range from walking pneumonia to sever infection

Name: Neisseria gonorrhoeae
Key Points: Causative agent of gonorrhea; Common cause of conjunctivitis in neonates
Treatment: Pelvic: Ceftriaxone (add azythro/doxy to cover chlamydia); Eye: Ceftriaxone

Name: Neisseria meningitidis
Key Points: Important cause of meningitis in adolescents and young adults
Laboratory: Oxidase positive - cytochrome C oxidase = blue; Requires blood and 5-10% CO2 for growth; Chocolate agar
Prevention: Vaccine - tretravalent conjugate vaccine; Cipro or rifampin prophylaxis for close contacts
Signs: Petechiae and/or purpura; Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome

Name: Nocardia
Key Points: Found in soil

Name: Norovirus
Key Points: Quick spread in close quarters - cruise ships, daycare, etc

Name: Opisthorchis
Key Points: Ingestion of raw fish

Name: Parvovirus B19
Disease: Fifth disease; Aplastic crisis in sickle cell; Fetal hydrops/abortion in pregnancy
Signs: Slapped cheek

Name: Plasmodium falciparum
Key Points: Causative agent of malaria; Anopheles mosquito vector
Laboratory: Microscopy (thick and thin); Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT) url:https://www.cdc.gov/malaria/diagnosis_treatment/rdt.html

Name: Plasmodium knowlesi
Key Points: Malaria in macaque monkeys or humans; Anopheles mosquito vector

Name: Plasmodium malariae
Key Points: Anopheles mosquito vector

Name: Plasmodium ovale
Key Points: Anopheles mosquito vector

Name: Plasmodium vivax
Key Points: Anopheles mosquito vector

Name: Pneumocystis jirovecii (PCP)
Key Points: AIDS defining; CD4 < 200

Name: Poliovirus
Key Points: Largely eliminated in most of world due to vaccination
General: Picornavirus; (+) ss-RNA; Humans only susceptible host; 3 serotypes
Prevention: Salk (IPV): formalin inactivated; Sabin (OPV): oral, live attenuated
Signs: Flaccid paralysis; Respiratory paralysis and death

Name: Porphyromonas gingivalis
Key Points: Associated with diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular diseases, adverse pregnancy outcomes

Name: Powassan
Signs: Flu-like symptoms; Fever; Rash; Aches; Chills

Name: Prion
General: Highly resistant to inactivation; Transmission: genetic, iatrogenic, ingestion
Disease: Kuru; Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease; Gerstmann-Streussler-Shanker disease; Fatal famililal insomnia variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
Signs: Dementia; Myoclonus; Extrapyramidal and pyramidal signs; Aphasia/apraxia/agnosia; Visual loss

Name: Proteus mirabilis
Laboratory: Urease positive (alkaline urine); Swarming motility in culture; Lactase negative; Indole negative; H2S positive

Name: Pseudomonas aeruginosa
General: Strict aerobes; Ubiquitous in environment (especially water); Particularly affects immunocompromised individuals
Laboratory: Oxidase positive; Pyocyanin pigment production; Lactase negative; Growth on MacConkey agar
Disease: Otitis externa ("swimmer's ear"); Folliculitis; Pneumonia in cystic fibrosis patients

Name: Rabies
Key Points: Bullet-shaped; Negri bodies
Laboratory: Staining of brain; Direct fluorescence antibody stain
Treatment: Wound cleansing; Human Rabies immune globulin; Rabies vaccination
Signs: Fever, headache, tingling, pain, itching at bite site; Hyperactivity, throat spasm, hydrophobia, hypersalivation, delirium, coma, death

Name: Rickettsia rickettsii
Key Points: SE United States; Tick born
Signs: Rash starts on wrists and ankles and spreads centrally and to palms and soles

Name: Rotavirus
Key Points: Most common cause of infantile diarrhea; Predominantly affects children < 2 years
General: Segmented dsRNA genome; Infects enterocyes of small intestinal villi
Signs: Nausea/vomting; Watery diarrhea; Loss of appetite

Name: Salmonella enterica
Key Points: Associated with raw eggs, chicken, ice cream
Laboratory: Non-lactose fermenter (Mac Conkey agar); H2S positive

Name: Salmonella enteriditis
Key Points: Pet turtles, reptiles, ducks, chickens
Signs: Abrupt onset; Low fever; Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea

Name: Salmonella typhi
Key Points: Causative agent of typhoid fever
Treatment: Fluoroquinolones; Ceftriaxone; Azithromycin; Screen for vulnerablity due to emerging antibiotic resistance
Prevention: Whole cell killed; Live attenuated (Ty21A); Purified Vi capsule vaccines
Disease: Typhoid fever; Osteomyelitis (sickle cell); Hepatitis; Cholecystitis; Pyelonephritis; Delirium, coma, deafness, meningitis
Signs: Early constipation; Later bloody diarrhea

Name: Sarcoptes scabiei
Signs: Intensely pruritic rash between fingers, on beltline, or other skin creases

Name: Schistosoma spp
Key Points: Freshwater snails (waters of Egypt)
Morphology: Haematobium: Single spine on end url:https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f2/Schistosoma_haematobium_egg_4843_lores.jpg; Mansoni: Single lateral spine url:https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9a/Schistosoma_mansoni_egg_4841_lores.jpg
Signs: Bloody diarrhea; Hematuria

Name: Shiga Toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC)
Key Points: Similar to EHEC

Name: Shigella boydii
Key Points: Fs of Shigella transmission: feces, fingers, fomites, flies
Laboratory: Ferment glucose; Oxidase negative; Non-lactose fermenter (Mac Conkey Agar)
Disease: Reiter's syndrome; Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS); Dysentery

Name: Shigella dysenteriae
Key Points: Fs of Shigella transmission: feces, fingers, fomites, flies
Laboratory: Ferment glucose; Oxidase negative; Non-lactose fermenter (Mac Conkey Agar)
Disease: Reiter's syndrome; Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS); Dysentery

Name: Shigella flexnerii
Key Points: Fs of Shigella transmission: feces, fingers, fomites, flies
Laboratory: Ferment glucose; Oxidase negative; Non-lactose fermenter (Mac Conkey Agar)
Disease: Reiter's syndrome; Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS); Dysentery

Name: Shigella sonnei
Key Points: Fs of Shigella transmission: feces, fingers, fomites, flies
Laboratory: Ferment glucose; Oxidase negative; Non-lactose fermenter (Mac Conkey Agar)
Disease: Reiter's syndrome; Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS); Dysentery

Name: Sporothrix schenkii
Key Points: Ascending infection of skin along path of lymphatics
General: Fungal spores introduced through cutaneous cuts and abrasions
Morphology: Cigar-shaped yeast; Dimorphic; Hyphae thin and branched
Treatment: Itraconazole, Saturated solution of potassium iodide

Name: St. Louis encephalitis virus
Signs: Flu-like symptoms; Fever, rash, aches, chills

Name: Staphylococcus aureus
Key Points: Common skin flora; Most common cause of skin infections, food poisoning, and osteomyelitis; MRSA strain common and problematic in health-care settings
Laboratory: Catalase positive; Oxidase negative; Coagulase positive
Treatment: Antibiotics; MRSA resistant to most beta-lactam drugs and treated with vancomycin
Disease: Otitis externa; Osteomyelitis; Skin infections; Food poisoning

Name: Staphylococcus epidermidis
Key Points: Classically infects implanted devices
Laboratory: Catalase positive; Oxidase negative; Coagulase negative

Name: Streptococcus agalactiae
Key Points: Most common cause of neonatal meningitis
General: Group B streptococci; Virulence factor = capsules
Laboratory: Catalase negative; Beta-hemolytic and bacitracin insensitive; CAMP test positive
Prevention: During labor: IV Penicillin G; Ampicillin

Name: Streptococcus pneumoniae
Key Points: Important cause of meningitis in infants/children and older adults; Classic respiratory bug
General: Major cause of typical community-acquired infections and otitis media
Treatment: Antibiotics (screen for sensitivity-many resistant to penicillin)
Disease: Acute otitis media (AOM); Pneumococcal pneumonia; Meningitis; Upper respiratory infection (URI)

Name: Streptococcus pyogenes
Key Points: Cause of "Step throat"; Common cause of necrotizing fasciitis
Disease: Tonsillitis; Rheumatic Fever; Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis; Scarlet fever (2 days after pharyngitis, sandpaper rash, strawberry tongue); Impetigo

Name: Strongyloides stercoralis
Key Points: Exacerbated by immunosuppressive therapy

Name: Taenia saginatum
Key Points: Associated with undercooked beef

Name: Taenia solium
Key Points: Associated with raw pork

Name: Toxoplasma gondii
Key Points: Found in cat feces and raw/undercooked meat; Avoid in pregnancy; AIDS defining; CD4 < 100
Treatment: Pyrimethamine, Sulfadiazine, and Folate x1 year; TMP-SMX or atovaquone (HIV with CD4 < 100)
Signs: Diffuse intracranial calcifications

Name: Treponema pallidum
Key Points: Disease presents in 3 stages with significant latency period; Advanced cases associated with neurologic sequelae
Signs: Stage 1: Chancre sore; Stage 2: rash progressing from trunk to entire body; Can enter latent (dormant) phase following Stage 2; Stage 3: organ damage, neurological symptoms (signs of posterior column deterioration)

Name: Trichinella spiralis
Key Points: Associated with raw pork

Name: Trichomonas vaginalis
Signs: Frothy green vaginal discharge; Foul-smelling odor; Strawberry cervix

Name: Tropheryma whippelii
Signs: Malabsorptive diarrhea; Migratory non-deforming arthritis

Name: Varicella Zoster Virus
Laboratory: Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells
Treatment: Famciclovir for shingles; Ayclovir for children 12+, adults, and immunocompromised
Signs: Fever; Headache; Vesicular lesions (think dew drops on a rose petal) url:https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-h6SRM2-8VWQ/TwChsh8W6EI/AAAAAAAAAOc/InmymMowONE/s1600/dewonrosepetal.jpg

Name: Venezuelan Equine Encephalitis (VEE)
Signs: Flu-like symptoms

Name: Vibrionaceae cholerae
Key Points: Comma-shaped rod; Can cause profuse, life-threatening diarrhea
General: GI effects due to enterotoxin that constitutively activates adenyl cylcase
Treatment: Oral rehydration salts; Ringers lactate for IV therapy
Prevention: Killed whole cell; Live attenuated vaccines
Signs: Rice water stool; Peripheral pulses absent, decreased blood pressure, sunken eyes, poor skin turgor, hyperventilation, muscle cramps

Name: Vibrionaceae parahaemolyticus
Key Points: Comma-shaped rod; Associated with raw oysters/shellfish and contaminated water
Signs: Acute watery diarrhea, occasionally with blood; Severe cramping, abdominal pain, vomiting

Name: West Nile virus
Key Points: Mosquito vector with bird host; High index of suspicion for sudden onset of encephalitis in adults >50 y.o. during summer/fall
Laboratory: ELISA for IgM in serum or CSF
Signs: Mild infection: sudden onset febrile illness, malaise, nausea and vomiting, headache; Severe infection: fever, weakness, rash on neck, trunk, arms, legs, myelitis, ataxia, seizures, optic neuritis, changes in mental status

Name: Western Equine Encephalitis (WEE)
Signs: Flu-like symptoms

Name: Yersinia enterocolitica
General: Grows well at room temperature and 4°C
Signs: Fever, abdominal pain, inflammatory diarrhea

Name: Yersinia pseudotuberculosis
General: Grows well at room temperature and 4°C
Signs: Fever, abdominal pain, inflammatory diarrhea

Name: Zika virus
Disease: Encephalitis; Microcephaly, intracerebral calcifications, hearing loss, vision abnormalities, lissencephaly, pachygyria, ventricular enlargement, arthrogryposis, muscular atrophy
Signs: Rash, fever, arthralgia, headache, myalgia
